Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
December 2011 
 
 
 
Kingdom of Bhutan: Strengthening Air Transport 
Regulatory and Operational Performance

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Bhutan requested capacity development technical assistance (TA) 
from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to strengthen air transport regulatory and operational 
performance. ADB approved the TA concept paper on 15 November 2011. On 1 September 
2011, an ADB fact-finding mission held discussions on preparations for the TA with the Ministry 
of Information and Communication (MOIC), the Department of Civil Aviation (DCA), and the 
Department  of  Public  Accounts  of  the  Ministry  of  Finance.  The  mission  reached  an 
understanding  with  the  government  on  the  TA  project’s  impact,  outcome,  outputs, 
implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing  arrangement,  and  terms  of  reference.1 The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Air transport activity in Bhutan is expected to increase substantially as a result of (i) the 
government’s continued effort to market tourist attractions in the country, and (ii) the introduction 
of domestic air travel to provide access to and promote tourism in the less-developed regions. In 
2010, the air passenger volume at Paro International Airport, the country’s only operational 
airport, reached about 127,000 passengers—more than triple the estimated 33,900 passengers 
in 2001. Based on the updated air traffic forecast, assuming physical capacity improvements 
keep pace with demand, air passenger traffic could grow to about 491,000 passengers per year 
by 2020, of which about 12% (60,000 passengers) would be carried on the new domestic 
services.  This  anticipated  traffic  growth  emphasizes  the  need  to  ensure  optimum  sector 
performance and service delivery in terms of safety, security, and capacity. 
 
3.  The  air  transport  sector  assessment,  carried  out  under  an  ongoing  ADB  project 
preparatory TA, has revealed inadequacies in several critical areas, particularly the institutional, 
legal, and regulatory frameworks, as well as the role and capacity of the DCA.2 Since being 
established in January 1986 under the MOIC, the DCA has been responsible for providing both 
the  regulatory  and  operational  functions  for  civil  aviation.  This  dual  role,  where  the  DCA 
regulates  its  own  operations,  creates  the  potential  for  conflict  of  interest.  The  DCA  has 
developed an organization plan to separate the two functions, although both functions would 
remain within the same organization and under the same overall leadership. In the interest of 
aviation safety and in keeping with best international practice, the regulatory and operational 
functions performed by the DCA need to be separated more clearly. Ideally, the DCA would 
evolve into a regulatory authority outside the government structure rather than functioning as a 
department of the government subject to the constraints of the civil service.3 The operational 
functions currently performed by the DCA could then be handed off to a commercial entity, 
incorporated as a government-owned company, free to function on a commercial basis. New 
legislation and amendments to existing laws would be required to facilitate this transformation. 
 
4.  The DCA currently has 193 employees and is substantively understaffed in several 
areas, particularly regulation and inspection. A review of the DCA operations concluded that it is 
unable to provide total and effective regulatory oversight of airworthiness, flight operations, and

aerodromes regulation because  of  staff shortages,  lack  of qualified  staff  in  several  of the 
required areas of inspection, and inadequate training and skills upgrading.4 With new domestic 
airports expected to become operational during 2012, it is essential to train and upgrade the 
skills of existing staff. 
 
5.  The Civil Aviation Act 2000, a revision of the first Civil Aviation Act enacted in 1990 and 
reenacted on 14 July 2000, serves as the enabling legislation for administration of civil aviation 
in Bhutan. The act is deficient as an instrument for regulating and administering civil aviation in 
several areas; it is also inconsistent in some areas. The Bhutan Air Navigation Regulations 
(BANRs)  were  intended  to  interpret  and  apply  the  provisions  of  the  act,  but  significant 
inconsistencies between the act and the BANRs have emerged and require reconciliation. The 
act needs to be updated and the BANRs must be readdressed to ensure consistency and 
completeness. 
 
6.  The TA—ADB’s first in the country’s air transport sector—is timely and targeted to 
strengthen  regulatory  and  operational  performance  by  improving  institutional,  legal,  and 
regulatory frameworks, as well as upgrading the DCA’s capacity. It will facilitate institutional and 
organizational  capacity  development  to  support  the  government’s  plan  to  develop  a  safe, 
reliable, and efficient network of domestic air transport connecting urban and rural centers. This 
will help overcome the current limitations of road transport and provide accessibility. It will also 
promote  tourism  and  high-value  agriculture  in  the  less-developed  regions.  The  TA  will 
complement  the  ensuing  ADB-assisted  project  in  the  2012  pipeline,  the  Air  Transport 
Connectivity Enhancement Project.5 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact will be improved air transport connectivity and the outcome will be improved 
air transport regulatory and operational performance. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The key activities of the TA are (i) preparing updates for the Civil Aviation Act 2000 and 
applicable BANRs to reflect the current needs; (ii) formulating a framework for restructuring the 
DCA and drafting necessary legislation, which will enable effective separation of the regulatory 
and operational functions, and provide the necessary autonomy; and (iii) providing technical 
training in the critical areas of regulatory oversight and airport operations. 
 
9.  The two international experts (civil aviation institutional specialist and civil aviation legal 
expert) and one national legal expert will be engaged to (i) review the act; (ii) determine and 
develop amendments to reflect the current needs in terms of empowerment, specification of 
delegated authority, and provision of authority where none  currently exists; (iii) review the 
current BANRs, identify any inconsistencies that need to be rectified, and compile appropriate 
international  regulations  for  updating;  (iv)  develop  a  preliminary  restructuring  and 
implementation plan for effective separation of regulatory and operational functions; and (v) 
assess and prioritize critical areas of technical training requirements for DCA staff.

10.  To enable restructuring of the DCA, a framework and legislation will be developed with 
the aim of separating its regulatory functions from its operations, which the government views 
as a fundamental need over the long term. The approach that might be most appropriate for 
Bhutan would be to create (i) a civil aviation authority to function as the regulator of civil 
aviation; and (ii) a corporate entity (an airports company) to function as the operator of the 
airports, air traffic, and the air navigation system in the country. This would require restructuring 
the DCA by establishing the civil aviation authority outside the government structure, reporting 
to a board, rather than functioning as a department of the government subject to the constraints 
of the civil service. The operational functions currently performed by the DCA would then be 
handed over to a government-owned airports company, free to function on a commercial basis. 
 
11.  To provide technical training in the critical areas of regulatory oversight and airport 
operations, key DCA staff will attend technical training courses conducted at internationally 
recognized civil aviation academies or institutions. The initial need assessment highlighted 
deficiencies in safety oversight airworthiness inspection, airport planning and operations, airport 
certification, and air traffic services. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis in the amount of $300,000 equivalent from 
ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV).6 The cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. The disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The MOIC will be the executing agency and the DCA will be the implementing agency 
for the TA. A project management unit is not envisaged. The government’s in-kind contribution 
will be the provision of office accommodation, support facilities, counterpart staff, and other 
logistical  support.  The  government  will  provide  all  available  reports,  existing  acts  and 
regulations,  and  other  pertinent  data.  It  will  also  facilitate  interagency  coordination  and 
applicable permits as necessary. The MOIC may use the advance payment facility to finance 
expenditures under the TA. 
 
14.  All  procurement  of  goods  and  works,  if  any,  under  the  TA  will  be  undertaken  in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). ADB will 
engage the consultants in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended  from  time  to  time).  For  the  main  portion  of  the  TA,  a  firm  of  two  international 
consultants and one national consultant will be recruited using the quality- and cost-based 
selection procedure, with biodata technical proposal and a 90:10 proportion of quality to cost.7 
The services will be implemented over about 6 months and will require about 3.5 person-months 
of international consultant services and 2 person-months of national consultant services. The 
outline terms of reference is in Appendix 3. 
 
15.  The expected outputs will be disseminated in the form of consultants’ reports comprising 
a report on DCA restructuring and implementation plan; and a report on (i) amendments to the

Civil Aviation Act 2000, (ii) amendments to the BANRs, and (iii) enabling legislation necessary 
to  adopt  the  DCA  restructuring  plan  to  separate  the  regulatory  and  operational  functions. 
Progress will be monitored using intended outcomes and outputs described in the design and 
monitoring framework (Appendix 1). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bhutan for Strengthening the Air Transport Regulatory and Operational 
Performance, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  7 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Background and Objectives 
1.  The Government of Bhutan requested capacity development technical assistance (TA) 
from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to (i) review the Civil Aviation Act 2000; (ii) determine 
and develop amendments to reflect the current needs in terms of empowerment, specification of 
delegated authority, and provision of authority where none currently exists; and (iii) review the 
current Bhutan Air Navigation Regulations (BANRs), identify any inconsistencies that need to be 
rectified, and compile appropriate international regulations for updating. To enable restructuring 
of the Department of Civil Aviation (DCA), a framework and legislation and/or amendment to the 
Civil Aviation Act will be developed to separate its regulatory functions from its operations. The 
goal is to create (i) a civil aviation authority to function as the regulator of civil aviation; and (ii) a 
corporate entity (an airports company) to function as the operator of the airports, air traffic, and 
the  air  navigation  system  in  the  country.  This  would  require  restructuring  the  DCA  by 
establishing the civil aviation authority outside the government structure, reporting to a board, 
rather than functioning as a department of the government subject to the constraints of the civil 
service. The operational functions currently performed by the DCA would then be handed over 
to a government-owned company airports company, free to function on a commercial basis.  
 
B.  Scope of Services 
2.  The indicative scope of services is described in paras. 3–8. 
 
3.  International  civil  aviation  institutional  specialist  and  team  leader  (1  person-
month). The consultant will 
(i)  develop  a  preliminary  restructuring  and  implementation  plan  for  effective 
separation of regulatory and operational functions with the aim of creating (a) a 
civil aviation authority to function as the regulator of civil aviation; and (b) a 
corporate entity (an airports company) to function as the operator of the airports, 
air traffic, and the air navigation system in the country; 
(ii)  assess the current technical personnel qualification and training (including the 
assessment  of  the  most  recent  International  Civil  Aviation  Organization’s 
Universal Safety Oversight Audit Programme, prioritize critical areas of technical 
training requirements for DCA staff, and assist the DCA in identifying appropriate 
courses and programs at internationally recognized civil aviation academies or 
institutions; and  
(iii)  provide oversight of the consultant team and ensure quality and timely outputs. 
 
4.  The consultant will have at least a bachelor’s degree or equivalent in a related field with 
15 or more years of relevant professional experience in civil aviation, combined with specialized 
experience in developing and/or implementing restructuring of civil aviation organizations, and 
developing technical training requirements. 
 
5.  International civil aviation regulatory lawyer (2.5 person-months). The consultant 
will 
(i)  review of the Civil Aviation Law 2000 and subsequent draft amendments; and 
determine and develop amendments to reflect the current needs in terms of 
empowerment, specification of delegated authority, and provision of authority 
where none currently exists;

(ii)  review the BANRs and prepare amendments, including the rectification of any 
inconsistencies and incorporating the best international standards;1 and 
(iii)  prepare legislation and/or amendments to the Civil Aviation Act to enable the 
separation  of  the  DCA  from  government,  based  on  the  approach  and 
restructuring  plan  formulated  by  the  international  civil  aviation  institutional 
specialist (i.e., creating a civil aviation authority and the airport company). 
 
6.  The consultant will have at least a bachelor’s degree or equivalent law with 10 or more 
years of relevant legal experience, including specialized work in drafting civil aviation acts and 
regulations.  
 
7.  National legal expert (2 person-months). The consultant will assist the international 
civil aviation legal experts with all applicable legal requirements in Bhutan. 
 
8.  The consultant will have at least a bachelor’s degree or equivalent in law with 10 or more 
years of general legal experience, including license or equivalent permit to practice law in 
Bhutan.

9.  The consulting services will be implemented over 6 months from the start date.
